1.4.3 a
Issue Descriptions
The contrast ratio between a control's text and its background is not at least 4.5:1 on hover and/or on focus (contrast-link-infocus-4.5-1, "issue", serious)
The contrast ratio between text and its background is not at least 4.5:1. (contrast-text-4.5-1, "issue", serious)
All or portions of text over an image do not meet the minimum 4.5:1 contrast requirement. (contrast-text-4.5-1-over-image, "issue", serious)
The contrast ratio between placeholder text and its background is not at least 4.5:1. (contrast-text-4.5-1-placeholder, "issue", serious)
Best Practices

Best Practices
Color Contrast on Visual Focus - Ideally, the visual focus indicator should have at least a 4.5 to 1 color contrast ratio. While the minimum requirement for WCAG is any visual focus be present including the simple default browser 1 px dotted outline, this may be very difficult to see. Note: In WCAG 2.1, SC 1.4.11 Non-Text Contrast requires contrast of 3 to 1 for visual focus. (contrast-focus-4.5-1, "best-practice", moderate, April 16, 2013)

Color contrast of 3 to 1 on icons - The color contrast of non-text visual information in icons should have a 3 to 1 color contrast ratio. Note: In WCAG 2.1, SC 1.4.11 Non-Text Contrast requires contrast of 3 to 1 for non-text icon parts required for understanding. (contrast-icon-3-1, "best-practice", moderate, February 1, 2016)

Color contrast of 4.5 to 1 on icons - The color contrast of non-text visual information in icons should have a 4.5 to 1 color contrast ratio. Note: In WCAG 2.1, SC 1.4.11 Non-Text Contrast requires contrast of 3 to 1 for non-text icon parts required for understanding. (contrast-icon-4.5-1, "best-practice", moderate, February 1, 2016)
Not an Issue
Text or images of text that are part of an inactive user interface component have no contrast requirement. (contrast-optional-disabled-controls, "issue", not an issue)

Text that is part of a logo or brand name has no minimum contrast requirement. (contrast-optional-logotype, "issue", not an issue)

Exceptions:
Regular Text: If the text is "regular", the requirement is a ratio 4.5 to 1. See 1.4.3.a Color Contrast (regular text).
Logotype: Text that is part of a logo or brand name has no contrast requirement.
Disabled Form Controls: Text related to a disabled form control (aka "inactive user interface component") has no contrast requirement.

Incidental Text: Text or images of text that are pure decoration, are a photo or graphical representation of an actual object, that are not visible to anyone, or that are part of a picture that contains significant other visual content, have no contrast requirement. Text is only purely decorative if the words can be rearranged or substituted without changing their purpose. Example: The cover page of a dictionary has random words in very light text in the background.

Issue Descriptions
The contrast ratio between a control's large text and its background is not at least 3:1 on hover and/or on focus. (contrast-link-infocus-3-1, "issue", serious)
The contrast ratio between large text and its background is not at least 3:1. (contrast-text-3-1, "issue", serious)
All or portions of large text over an image do not meet the minimum 3:1 contrast requirement. (contrast-text-3-1-over-image, "issue", serious)
Best Practices

Best Practices
Color contrast on visual focus - The visual focus indicator should have at least a 3 to 1 color contrast ratio. Note: In WCAG 2.1, SC 1.4.11 Non-Text Contrast requires contrast of 3 to 1 for visual focus. (contrast-focus-3-1, "best-practice", moderate, April 16, 2013)

Color contrast of 3 to 1 on icons - The color contrast of non-text visual information in icons should have a 3 to 1 color contrast ratio. Note: In WCAG 2.1, SC 1.4.11 Non-Text Contrast requires contrast of 3 to 1 for non-text icon parts required for understanding. (contrast-icon-3-1, "best-practice", moderate, February 1, 2016)
Not an Issue

1.4.11.a
Use this checkpoint to log issues related to components in their default state (e.g. not checked, not selected, not focused, not hovered, not pressed). Use checkpoint 1.4.11.b for issues related to components not in their default state.
Identify all active (NOT disabled) user components on the page. This includes form elements, buttons, sliders, and other controls.

For each active user component, identify the visual characteristics that indicate the component's purpose or type (e.g. is it a checkbox, text field, slider, switch, etc.).
Note: This Success Criterion does not require a component to have a visual boundary indicating the hit area, but if the visual indicator of the boundary is the ONLY way to identify the component, it must have sufficient contrast.
Do NOT test disabled components.
Do NOT test the contrast of the visual boundary of a button that has text or an icon inside of it.

Do NOT test the contrast of the visual boundary of a button that has text or an icon inside of it.
Do NOT test the contrast of the visual boundary of a text input that has text (that has at least 4.5:1 contrast with its background) inside of it.
Do NOT test the contrast of the visual boundary if it is the default color set by the browser.
If a user component is found that relies on its boundary to identify the control and the boundary is NOT the browser default color for that control:
Use the CSS panel or design documentation to locate the relevant hex color codes.

Use the CSS panel or design documentation to locate the relevant hex color codes.
If the hex codes cannot be obtained: Take a screenshot and then open it on a desktop computer.
Use a tool such as Deque Color Contrast Analyzer to pick and/or analyze:
A representative pixel of the component's visual edge.
A representative pixel of the primary surrounding color(s).
Confirm that the contrast ratio is at least 3 to 1.
Things to think about

Confirm that the contrast ratio is at least 3 to 1.
Things to think about
One method to determine if the color of a control or its state is the browser's default color is to open the page in other browsers and see if the color changes. For example, Chrome and Firefox and Safari have different default focus indicator colors and different checkbox, radio button and text input outline colors. If the color changes from one browser to another, it is highly likely that the control or state is using the browser's default color.
When picking colors with an eyedropper tool, keep in mind that user agent rendering of lines involves smoothing. As you choose a representative pixel of an element, do not select a smoothing pixel.

Important quote from Understanding 1.4.11 "This success criteria does not require that controls have a visual boundary indicating the hit area, but if the visual indicator of the control is the only way to identify the control, then that indicator must have sufficient contrast. If text (or an icon) within a button or text inside a text input is visible and there is no visual indication of the hit area then the Success Criterion is passed. If a button with text also has a colored border, since the border does not provide the only indication there is no contrast requirement beyond the text contrast (1.4.3 Contrast (Minimum))."

Issue Descriptions
The visual boundary of an active user interface component lacks 3 to 1 contrast ratio. (contrast-uic-active-3-1, "issue", serious)
Best Practices
Color contrast of 4.5 to 1 on icons - The color contrast of non-text visual information in icons should have a 4.5 to 1 color contrast ratio. Note: In WCAG 2.1, SC 1.4.11 Non-Text Contrast requires contrast of 3 to 1 for non-text icon parts required for understanding. (contrast-icon-4.5-1, "best-practice", moderate, February 1, 2016)

Active user interface component contrast both - Ideally, an active user interface component could have a contrast of 3 to 1 with both the inner and outer adjacent background colors. (contrast-uic-active-both-3-1, "best-practice", minor, June 5, 2018)
Active user interface component contrast better than default - Ideally, if the browser default rendering of an active user interface component has less than a 3 to 1 contrast, the default is improved by an author supplied style that at least meets the 3 to 1 contrast. (contrast-uic-active-browser-default, "best-practice", moderate, June 5, 2018)

Default color of component contrasts 3 to 1 with author background - Ideally, if the browser default rendering of component has less than a 3 to 1 contrast with the author defined background color, the contrast is improved to at least a 3 to 1. (contrast-uic-active-browser-default-back, "best-practice", moderate, June 5, 2018)
Contrast between active and inactive components at least 3 to 1 - Ideally, an active user interface component should have a contrast of 3 to 1 with inactive components. (contrast-uic-active-inactive, "best-practice", moderate, June 5, 2018)

Active user interface component visual boundary - Ideally, an active user interface component should have a visual boundary. (contrast-uic-active-no-visual, "best-practice", minor, June 5, 2018)
Inactive user interface component contrast - Ideally, an inactive user interface component should be visible to a person with low vision. (contrast-uic-inactive-3-1, "best-practice", moderate, June 5, 2018)
1.4.11.b

1.4.11.b
Use this checkpoint to log issues related to controls not in their default state (e.g. they are checked, selected, focused, hovered, pressed). Use checkpoint 1.4.11.a for issues related to controls in their default state.
Identify all active (NOT disabled) user components on the page. This includes form elements, buttons, links, sliders, tabs, and other controls.
For each active user component, identify all the visual states of that component. Common states include: checked, selected, focused, hovered, pressed.
Do NOT test disabled components.

Do NOT test disabled components.
Do NOT test the contrast of the state if it is the default color set by the browser. HOWEVER: The focus indicator MUST be visible under 2.4.7. Do report an issue under 2.4.7.a if you cannot see the visual focus (even if it is the browser default).
Do NOT test the contrast of the hover state indicator. DO test that the component boundaries and any graphics (icons) needed to understand the purpose of the control still meet 1.4.11 requirements while hovered. If text falls below text contrast requirements, log that under a 1.4.3 Contrast (Minimum) checkpoint.

If the appearance of the component is NOT the browser default for that control, then test to see if:
All images or icons or boundaries that are required to understand the purpose of the control maintain a contrast of at least 3 to 1 in all states.
The visual information necessary to indicate the state (e.g. checked, selected, focused, etc.) has a minimum 3 to 1 contrast ratio.
Focus indicators - When a focus indicator appears:
Outside the component, it needs to contrast with the background that the component is on.

Outside the component, it needs to contrast with the background that the component is on.
Inside the component, it needs to contrast with the adjacent color(s) within the component.
As the border of the component (inside the component and adjacent to the outside), it needs to contrast with both adjacent colors.
Appears partly inside and partly outside, either part of the focus indicator can contrast with the adjacent colors.
Note: Understanding Success Criterion 1.4.11: Non-text Contrast provides many useful visual examples of passing and failing scenarios.
To test:

To test:
Use the CSS panel or design documentation to locate the relevant hex color codes.
If the hex codes cannot be obtained: Take a screenshot and then open it on a desktop computer.
Use a tool such as Deque Color Contrast Analyzer to pick and/or analyze:
A representative pixel of the color of the state's visual edge.
A representative pixel of the primary surrounding color(s).
Confirm that the contrast ratio is at least 3 to 1.
Things to think about

Confirm that the contrast ratio is at least 3 to 1.
Things to think about
When analyzing focus indicators, be sure to take into account more than just the focus ring that may appear around a link or other control. Additional indicators that can also be used to meet this requirement include underlining link text on focus and the cursor or caret in a text input field.

Sometimes a control's state (focused, selected, pressed, etc) is ONLY indicated by a change in the background color of the control. If the contrast between the backgrounds of the state being tested and the default state is less than 3:1, only log ONE issue under 1.4.1.a Use of Color.
A commonly overlooked failure of this checkpoint is the indicator of the currently selected or focused option in a select element or combobox.

One method to determine if the color of a control or its state is the browser's default color is to open the page in other browsers and see if the color changes. For example, Chrome and Firefox and Safari have different default focus indicator colors and different checkbox, radio button and text input outline colors. If the color changes from one browser to another, it is highly likely that the control or state is using the browser's default color.

When picking colors with an eyedropper tool, keep in mind that user agent rendering of lines involves smoothing. As you choose a representative pixel of an element, do not select a smoothing pixel.
Issue Descriptions
Focus indicator lacks 3 to 1 contrast ratio. (contrast-focus-indicator, "issue", serious)
The state of an active component lacks 3 to 1 contrast ratio. (contrast-uic-active-3-1-state, "issue", serious)
Best Practices

Best Practices
Color Contrast on Visual Focus - Ideally, the visual focus indicator should have at least a 4.5 to 1 color contrast ratio. While the minimum requirement for WCAG is any visual focus be present including the simple default browser 1 px dotted outline, this may be very difficult to see. Note: In WCAG 2.1, SC 1.4.11 Non-Text Contrast requires contrast of 3 to 1 for visual focus. (contrast-focus-4.5-1, "best-practice", moderate, April 16, 2013)

State of active component contrast both - Ideally, the state of an active user interface component could have a contrast of 3 to 1 with both the inner and outer adjacent background colors. (contrast-uic-active-both-3-1-state, "best-practice", minor, June 5, 2018)

Default color of component state contrasts 3 to 1 with author background - Ideally, if the browser default rendering of the state of a component has less than a 3 to 1 contrast with the author defined background color, the contrast is improved to at least a 3 to 1. (contrast-uic-active-browser-default-back-state, "best-practice", moderate, June 5, 2018)

State of active component contrast better than default - Ideally, if the browser default rendering of the state of an active user interface component has less than a 3 to 1 contrast, the default is improved by an author supplied style that at least meets the 3 to 1 contrast. (contrast-uic-active-browser-default-state, "best-practice", moderate, June 5, 2018)
State of active component contrast no anti-aliasing - In a perfect world, the state of an active component would have a 3 to 1 contrast with no anti-aliasing. (contrast-uic-state-anti-aliasing, "best-practice", minor, June 5, 2018)

Contrast between component states at least 3 to 1 - Ideally, a component state should have a contrast of 3 to 1 with the other states of that component. (contrast-uic-states, "best-practice", moderate, June 5, 2018)
1.4.11.c
1.4.11.c Non-Text Contrast - Graphical Objects
Overview
General - Parts of images and other graphical objects (that are required to understand the content) must have a contrast ratio of 3 to 1 against adjacent color(s). Exceptions exist.

HTML - Parts of images and other graphical objects (that are required to understand the content) must have a contrast ratio of 3 to 1 against adjacent color(s). Exceptions exist.
Use this checkpoint to log issues related to graphics for static (e.g. charts, informative icons, infographics, etc.) and interactive content (e.g. button icons).
Identify each graphic on the page that includes information required for understanding the content (i.e. excluding graphics which have visible text for the same information, or are decorative).

For each graphic, in your mind, break down that graphic into the smallest meaningful pieces. Each meaningful piece is a graphical object.
For each meaningful piece of the graphic (graphical object), check the contrast of the graphical object against its adjacent color(s). If there are multiple colors and/or a gradient, choose the least contrasting area to test.
Use the CSS panel or design documentation to locate the relevant hex color codes.
If the hex codes cannot be obtained: Take a screenshot and then open it on a desktop computer.

If the hex codes cannot be obtained: Take a screenshot and then open it on a desktop computer.
Use a tool such as Deque Color Contrast Analyzer to pick and/or analyze:
A representative pixel of the graphical object's visual edge.
A representative pixel of the primary surrounding color(s).
Confirm that the contrast ratio is at least 3 to 1.
If the least-contrasting area is less than 3:1, assume that area is invisible. Is the graphical object still understandable?

If there is enough of the graphical object with sufficient contrast to understand, it passes, else fail. Gestalt principles such as the "law of continuity" can be used to ignore minor overlaps with other graphical objects or colors.
Things to think about
Logos are exempt from 1.4.11 Non-text Contrast requirements.
When picking colors with an eyedropper tool, keep in mind that user agent rendering of lines involves smoothing. As you choose a representative pixel of an element, do not select a smoothing pixel.
Issue Descriptions

Issue Descriptions
Parts of graphics (required to understand the content) do not have a contrast ratio of 3 to 1 against adjacent color(s). (contrast-graphical-objects-3-1, "issue", serious)
Parts of an icon (with no text) do not have a contrast ratio of 3 to 1 against adjacent color(s). These icon parts are required for understanding. (contrast-graphical-objects-icon-3-1, "issue", serious)
Best Practices

Best Practices
Graphical object with text has 3 to 1 contrast ratio - A graphical object has visible text that conveys the same information as the graphical object. The graphical object (non-text) should have at least a 3 to 1 color contrast ratio. (contrast-graphical-objects-3-1-plus-text, "best-practice", moderate, June 5, 2018)
Graphical object contrast no anti-aliasing - In a perfect world, the graphical object would have a 3 to 1 contrast with no anti-aliasing. (contrast-graphical-objects-anti-aliasing, "best-practice", minor, June 5, 2018)

Graphical object has 3 to 1 contrast ratio with both - Ideally, a graphical object could have a contrast of 3 to 1 with both the inner and outer adjacent background colors. (contrast-graphical-objects-both-3-1, "best-practice", moderate, June 5, 2018)
Flag graphical object has 3 to 1 contrast - In a perfect world, graphical object(s) in a flag (like for a state, country or organization) would have at least a contrast of 3 to 1. (contrast-graphical-objects-flag, "best-practice", minor, June 5, 2018)

Crossing data lines have 3 to 1 contrast - Ideally, crossing data lines would have at least a contrast of 3 to 1. (contrast-graphical-objects-line-cross, "best-practice", moderate, June 5, 2018)
Logo graphical object has 3 to 1 contrast - Ideally, graphical object(s) in a Logo should have a contrast of 3 to 1. (contrast-graphical-objects-logo, "best-practice", moderate, June 5, 2018)

Color contrast of 4.5 to 1 on icons - The color contrast of non-text visual information in icons should have a 4.5 to 1 color contrast ratio. Note: In WCAG 2.1, SC 1.4.11 Non-Text Contrast requires contrast of 3 to 1 for non-text icon parts required for understanding. (contrast-icon-4.5-1, "best-practice", moderate, February 1, 2016)

2.1.1.a Keyboard
Overview
General - All functionalities must be available using the keyboard, unless the functionality cannot be accomplished in any known way using a keyboard.
HTML - Page functionalities must be available using the keyboard, unless the functionality cannot be accomplished in any known way using a keyboard.
This checkpoint MUST be tested with the screen reader turned OFF and ALSO with the screen reader turned ON.
Visually explore the screen to discover all of the functionality that is available to someone using a mouse.

Ensure that the equivalent functionality is available using only the keyboard.
Use the TAB key to navigate focus among buttons, links, form inputs, links, menu items, tab panels, accordions, and other interactive UI elements.
Use SHIFT-TAB to navigate the focus in the reverse direction through all interactive UI elements.
You may need to use the UP, DOWN, RIGHT or LEFT arrow keys to move focus within elements including elements such as: radio buttons, select (drop down) elements, menus, tabs, and accordions.

Ensure that every interactive element can be focused with via keyboard and that the ENTER key or the SPACEBAR selects or activates the interactive UI element that has focus.
If an interactive element is not keyboard accessible it may still pass this checkpoint if at least one of the following is true:
Equivalent functionality is available on the same screen in a keyboard-accessible way.

Equivalent functionality is available on the same screen in a keyboard-accessible way.
An alternate accessible version of the functionality is available on a different screen AND the link to the accessible alternate version is clearly identified on the current screen. (More information about Understanding Conforming Alternate Versions.)

Exception (rare): The underlying function requires input that depends on the path of the user's movement and not just the endpoints. Examples include activities like: freehand drawing, watercolor painting, and flying a helicopter through an obstacle course. The input required for these activities cannot currently be done from the keyboard in any known fashion without requiring an inordinate number of keystrokes.
Things to think about
The use of the ESC key to dismiss a modal dialog is a Best Practice.

Things to think about
The use of the ESC key to dismiss a modal dialog is a Best Practice.
Examples of activities commonly done by mouse that can and must be made keyboard accessible include:
Drag and drop
Resizing windows
Drawing a straight line
Drawing preset geometric shapes (examples: circle, square, triangle, star, spiral)
Examples of conforming alternate versions:
Note: To be a valid Conforming Alternate Version it must "provide all of the same information and functionality".

Passes: A web site includes a map view that supports a mouse only event handler to zoom into the map content, and mouse only drag gestures to move the visible area. Keyboard accessible [+] and [-] buttons provide the same functionality to zoom in and out, and arrow buttons to move the visible area in all directions.

Passes: A news site has a carousel with 5 news stories and only one story is visible at a time. At the bottom of the carousel are 5 dots representing each story that can only be triggered with a mouse. To the left and right of the carousel, a next and previous arrow button is available for both keyboard and mouse users. Mouse users can navigate to the different stories by clicking on either the dots or the next/previous arrows. The keyboard only user can use the accessible next and previous buttons to perform the same functionality.

Fails: A calendar picker is not accessible via keyboard. Only mouse users can access (see) the calendar and pick dates directly from the calendar. Keyboard only users must use an edit field to enter the date, and they cannot see the calendar. This fails because the keyboard only user is at a disadvantage because they cannot see all the information that the calendar view provides. Note: information is not limited to text content. Information can also be conveyed by visual relationships, grouping, heading structure, and other context dependent cues.
Issue Descriptions

Issue Descriptions
There is no way to perform the function using only the keyboard on the same screen or on a qualifying conforming alternate version. (keyboard-inaccessible, "issue", critical)
In page links are not keyboard operable. (keyboard-inpage-link-not-accessible, "issue", moderate)
Action cannot be performed using switch control. (keyboard-not-switch-accessible, "issue", critical)
Action cannot be performed with a screen reader turned on. (keyboard-not-touch-accessible, "issue", critical)

Action cannot be performed using Voice Control. (keyboard-not-voice-control-accessible, "issue", critical)
The method to dismiss/close the modal/alert without submitting data is not keyboard accessible. (modal-forces-submission, "issue", critical)
The modal dialog is missing a close button and there is no way to close the modal with a keyboard. (modal-unclosable, "issue", critical)
Best Practices

Best Practices
Instructions should be provided for non-standard key interactions - Instructions should be provided to explain the non-standard keyboard interaction used to access an element. (keyboard-nonstandard-no-instructions, "best-practice", critical, January 8, 2019)
ESC for modals - Modals or layers that appear should close on ESC. (modal-no-esc, "best-practice", minor, March 26, 2013)
Provide a button to close modal or layer - A modal or layer that appears should have a button to close it other than just the ESC key. (modal-only-esc, "best-practice", minor, February 13, 2020)

2.1.2.a Keyboard Trap
2.1.2.a Keyboard Trap
Overview
General - The focus of the keyboard, or equivalent device, must not be locked or trapped in a particular element and the user must be able to navigate to and from all navigable elements using only this device.

HTML - The focus of the keyboard, or equivalent device, must not be locked or trapped in a particular element and the user must be able to navigate to and from all navigable elements using only this device.
This checkpoint MUST be tested with the screen reader turned OFF and ALSO with the screen reader turned ON.
Using only the keyboard as you navigate through the page, verify that keyboard focus is never trapped (stuck) on or in a component.
Use the TAB key to navigate focus among buttons, links, form inputs, links, menu items, tab panels, accordions, and other interactive UI elements.

Use SHIFT-TAB to navigate the focus in the reverse direction through all interactive UI elements.
If TAB or SHIFT-TAB do not work, also try any and all of the following:
Standard exit keys (Enter, Spacebar, ESC)
Up, down, right, left arrow keys
If moving away from a component requires more than TAB or SHIFT-TAB, unmodified arrow keys, Enter, Spacebar, or ESC, verify that the user is provided instructions for moving focus away.
Issue Descriptions
There is a keyboard trap. (keyboard-trap, "issue", critical)

Issue Descriptions
There is a keyboard trap. (keyboard-trap, "issue", critical)
Screen reader focus is trapped in an element. (keyboard-trap-screen-reader, "issue", critical)
The dialog cannot be dismissed when the screen reader is turned on. (keyboard-trap-screen-reader-dialog, "issue", critical)
The dialog cannot be dismissed using switch control. (keyboard-trap-switch, "issue", critical)
Switch control focus is trapped in a control. (keyboard-trap-switch-dialog, "issue", critical)
2.4.3.a Focus Order
Overview

2.4.3.a Focus Order
Overview
General - The navigation order of links, form elements, etc. must preserve the meaning and operability of the content.
HTML - The navigation order of links, form elements, etc. must preserve the meaning and operability of the content.
Testing Methodology
Desktop Web - Manual
Testing for this checkpoint can be accomplished using either the "Manual" methodology or the "Assistive Technology" methodology or a combination of both.
Tab order:
Place the cursor in the URL field of your browser.
Press the Tab key until focus moves into the page.

Press the Tab key until focus moves into the page.
Continue pressing Tab until you reach the end of the document, while ensuring that focus moves from element to element in a way that preserves the meaning and operability of the content and does not jump around erratically.
In-page interactions:
Activate in-page links or interactions, such as back to top links, skip to main content links, links to or from footnotes, and other in-page navigation links.

Ensure that when visual focus is moved (i.e. the viewport is shifted), programmatic focus (i.e. keyboard focus) is also moved to the intended target.
Interactive elements:
Navigate to interactive elements such as buttons, links, or tabs that show or hide content.
Activate or interact with the elements using Enter, Spacebar, or arrow keys, as appropriate.
When content is added or removed, navigate through the content (using tab or arrow keys as appropriate) to ensure that the focus order preserves meaning and operability.
Continue to press tab to move past the content (unless focus is intended to be trapped such as in a modal dialog) to ensure focus order preserves meaning and operability.

Note: For an element to be considered a modal dialog and therefore keep focus while the element is open, it must be truly "modal". That means that while the modal dialog is open, users cannot interact with content outside the element. Content outside an active dialog is typically visually obscured or dimmed. Popups, tooltips, or other overlays often do not meet the definition of "modal" and therefore keyboard and screen reader focus are not required to be maintained within when they are not truly "modal".

Repeat steps 2 and 3 if the interactive content introduces additional interactive functionality.
Things to think about
Focus does NOT have to move in the exact visual order of left-to-right and top-to-bottom. Only log an issue if the focus order negatively impacts the "meaning or operability" of the content.
If it is difficult to tell where focus is, use a tool such as the Force Focus bookmarklet to make focus obvious.
It is not a failure if non-interactive content receives keyboard focus.

It is not a failure if non-interactive content receives keyboard focus.
It is not a failure if the initial focus is set to a place within the page (like the search field on google.com or a login field on a bank site), because it does not destroy the meaning of the page. A logical reading order is still available to AT users.
Common failures:
When a modal dialog is opened, focus is not explicitly placed on or in the modal dialog
When a modal dialog is closed, focus is not explicitly placed back on the trigger or another a logical location in the workflow.

When a modal dialog is opened, focus is not maintained within the modal dialog.
When activating a button causes the button to be removed from the screen, focus is not explicitly placed on a logical location in the workflow.
Some JavaScript frameworks inject new content at the end of the DOM (while positioning it via CSS) and send focus to it, however tabbing or shift-tabbing away from the element may reveal focus order problems.
Issue Descriptions

Issue Descriptions
Keyboard focus is lost or placed on the wrong element during user interaction, content refresh or update, or other reason. (focus-lost, "issue", serious)
Keyboard focus is not maintained within the modal. It is possible to tab out of the modal. (focus-modal-moves-outside, "issue", serious)
Switch control focus is not maintained within the modal. Switch control users can access content behind the modal dialog. (focus-modal-moves-outside-switch, "issue", serious)
When the modal dialog is activated, keyboard focus is not placed on/in it. (focus-modal-none, "issue", serious)

When the modal dialog or similar element is closed, keyboard focus is not returned to the triggering element. (focus-modal-not-returned, "issue", serious)
Keyboard focus does not follow visual focus or move to the intended target, such as with a "return to top" link. (focus-not-moved, "issue", moderate)

Abstract

Abstract
Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 covers a wide range of recommendations for making Web content more accessible. Following these guidelines will make content more accessible to a wider range of people with disabilities, including accommodations for blindness and low vision, deafness and hearing loss, limited movement, speech disabilities, photosensitivity, and combinations of these, and some accommodation for learning disabilities and cognitive limitations; but will not address every user need for people with these disabilities. These guidelines address accessibility of web content on desktops, laptops, tablets, and mobile devices. Following these guidelines will also often make Web content more usable to users in general.

WCAG 2.1 success criteria are written as testable statements that are not technology-specific. Guidance about satisfying the success criteria in specific technologies, as well as general information about interpreting the success criteria, is provided in separate documents. See Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) Overview for an introduction and links to WCAG technical and educational material.

WCAG 2.1 extends Web Content Accessibility Guidelines 2.0 [WCAG20], which was published as a W3C Recommendation December 2008. Content that conforms to WCAG 2.1 also conforms to WCAG 2.0. The WG intends that for policies requiring conformance to WCAG 2.0, WCAG 2.1 can provide an alternate means of conformance. The publication of WCAG 2.1 does not deprecate or supersede WCAG 2.0. While WCAG 2.0 remains a W3C Recommendation, the W3C advises the use of WCAG 2.1 to maximize future applicability of accessibility efforts. The W3C also encourages use of the most current version of WCAG when developing or updating Web accessibility policies.

Background on WCAG 2
Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 defines how to make Web content more accessible to people with disabilities. Accessibility involves a wide range of disabilities, including visual, auditory, physical, speech, cognitive, language, learning, and neurological disabilities. Although these guidelines cover a wide range of issues, they are not able to address the needs of people with all types, degrees, and combinations of disability. These guidelines also make Web content more usable by older individuals with changing abilities due to aging and often improve usability for users in general.

WCAG 2.1 is developed through the W3C process in cooperation with individuals and organizations around the world, with a goal of providing a shared standard for Web content accessibility that meets the needs of individuals, organizations, and governments internationally. WCAG 2.1 builds on WCAG 2.0 [WCAG20], which in turn built on WCAG 1.0 [WAI-WEBCONTENT] and is designed to apply broadly to different Web technologies now and in the future, and to be testable with a combination of automated testing and human evaluation. For an introduction to WCAG, see the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) Overview.

Significant challenges were encountered in defining additional criteria to address cognitive, language, and learning disabilities, including a short timeline for development as well as challenges in reaching consensus on testability, implementability, and international considerations of proposals. Work will carry on in this area in future versions of WCAG. We encourage authors to refer to our supplemental guidance on improving inclusion for people with disabilities, including learning and cognitive disabilities, people with low-vision, and more.

Web accessibility depends not only on accessible content but also on accessible Web browsers and other user agents. Authoring tools also have an important role in Web accessibility. For an overview of how these components of Web development and interaction work together, see:
Essential Components of Web Accessibility
User Agent Accessibility Guidelines (UAAG) Overview
Authoring Tool Accessibility Guidelines (ATAG) Overview
Where this document refers to WCAG 2 it is intended to mean any and all versions of WCAG that start with 2.
WCAG 2 Layers of Guidance

WCAG 2 Layers of Guidance
The individuals and organizations that use WCAG vary widely and include Web designers and developers, policy makers, purchasing agents, teachers, and students. In order to meet the varying needs of this audience, several layers of guidance are provided including overall principles, general guidelines, testable success criteria and a rich collection of sufficient techniques, advisory techniques, and documented common failures with examples, resource links and code.

Principles - At the top are four principles that provide the foundation for Web accessibility: perceivable, operable, understandable, and robust. See also Understanding the Four Principles of Accessibility.
Guidelines - Under the principles are guidelines. The 13 guidelines provide the basic goals that authors should work toward in order to make content more accessible to users with different disabilities. The guidelines are not testable, but provide the framework and overall objectives to help authors understand the success criteria and better implement the techniques.

Success Criteria - For each guideline, testable success criteria are provided to allow WCAG 2.1 to be used where requirements and conformance testing are necessary such as in design specification, purchasing, regulation, and contractual agreements. In order to meet the needs of different groups and different situations, three levels of conformance are defined: A (lowest), AA, and AAA (highest). Additional information on WCAG levels can be found in Understanding Levels of Conformance.

Sufficient and Advisory Techniques - For each of the guidelines and success criteria in the WCAG 2.1 document itself, the working group has also documented a wide variety of techniques. The techniques are informative and fall into two categories: those that are sufficient for meeting the success criteria and those that are advisory. The advisory techniques go beyond what is required by the individual success criteria and allow authors to better address the guidelines. Some advisory techniques address accessibility barriers that are not covered by the testable success criteria. Where common failures are known, these are also documented. See also Sufficient and Advisory Techniques in Understanding WCAG 2.1.

All of these layers of guidance (principles, guidelines, success criteria, and sufficient and advisory techniques) work together to provide guidance on how to make content more accessible. Authors are encouraged to view and apply all layers that they are able to, including the advisory techniques, in order to best address the needs of the widest possible range of users.

Note that even content that conforms at the highest level (AAA) will not be accessible to individuals with all types, degrees, or combinations of disability, particularly in the cognitive language and learning areas. Authors are encouraged to consider the full range of techniques, including the advisory techniques, as well as to seek relevant advice about current best practice to ensure that Web content is accessible, as far as possible, to this community. Metadata may assist users in finding content most suitable for their needs.
WCAG 2.1 Supporting Documents

WCAG 2.1 Supporting Documents
The WCAG 2.1 document is designed to meet the needs of those who need a stable, referenceable technical standard. Other documents, called supporting documents, are based on the WCAG 2.1 document and address other important purposes, including the ability to be updated to describe how WCAG would be applied with new technologies. Supporting documents include:

How to Meet WCAG 2.1 - A customizable quick reference to WCAG 2.1 that includes all of the guidelines, success criteria, and techniques for authors to use as they are developing and evaluating Web content. This includes content from WCAG 2.0 and WCAG 2.1 and can be filtered in many ways to help authors focus on relevant content.
Understanding WCAG 2.1 - A guide to understanding and implementing WCAG 2.1. There is a short "Understanding" document for each guideline and success criterion in WCAG 2.1 as well as key topics.

Techniques for WCAG 2.1 - A collection of techniques and common failures, each in a separate document that includes a description, examples, code and tests.
The WCAG Documents - A diagram and description of how the technical documents are related and linked.

See Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) Overview for a description of the WCAG 2.1 supporting material, including education resources related to WCAG 2. Additional resources covering topics such as the business case for Web accessibility, planning implementation to improve the accessibility of Web sites, and accessibility policies are listed in WAI Resources.
Requirements for WCAG 2.1

Requirements for WCAG 2.1
WCAG 2.1 meets a set of requirements for WCAG 2.1 which, in turn, inherit requirements from WCAG 2.0. Requirements structure the overall framework of guidelines and ensure backwards compatibility. The Working Group also used a less formal set of acceptance criteria for success criteria, to help ensure success criteria are similar in style and quality to those in WCAG 2.0. These requirements constrained what could be included in WCAG 2.1. This constraint was important to preserve its nature as a dot-release of WCAG 2.
Comparison with WCAG 2.0

Comparison with WCAG 2.0
WCAG 2.1 was initiated with the goal to improve accessibility guidance for three major groups: users with cognitive or learning disabilities, users with low vision, and users with disabilities on mobile devices. Many ways to meet these needs were proposed and evaluated, and a set of these were refined by the Working Group. Structural requirements inherited from WCAG 2.0, clarity and impact of proposals, and timeline led to the final set of success criteria included in this version. The Working Group considers that WCAG 2.1 incrementally advances web content accessibility guidance for all these areas, but underscores that not all user needs are met by these guidelines.

WCAG 2.1 builds on and is backwards compatible with WCAG 2.0, meaning web pages that conform to WCAG 2.1 also conform to WCAG 2.0. Authors that are required by policy to conform with WCAG 2.0 will be able to update content to WCAG 2.1 without losing conformance with WCAG 2.0. WCAG 2.1 extends WCAG 2.0 by adding new success criteria, definitions to support them, guidelines to organize the additions, and a couple additions to the conformance section. Numbering in WCAG 2.1

Numbering in WCAG 2.1
In order to avoid confusion for implementers for whom backwards compatibility to WCAG 2.0 is important, new success criteria in WCAG 2.1 have been appended to the end of the set of success criteria within their guideline. This avoids the need to change the section number of success criteria from WCAG 2.0, which would be caused by inserting new success criteria between existing success criteria in the guideline, but it means success criteria in each guideline are no longer grouped by conformance level. The order of success criteria within each guideline does not imply information about conformance level; only the conformance level indicator (A / AA / AAA) on the success criterion itself indicates this. The WCAG 2.1 Quick Reference provides ways to view success criteria grouped by conformance level, along with many other filter and sort options.

Conformance to WCAG 2.1
WCAG 2.1 uses the same conformance model as WCAG 2.0 with a couple additions, which is described in the Conformance section. It is intended that sites that conform to WCAG 2.1 also conform to WCAG 2.0, which means they meet the requirements of any policies that reference WCAG 2.0, while also better meeting the needs of users on the current Web.
Later Versions of Accessibility Guidelines

Later Versions of Accessibility Guidelines
In parallel with WCAG 2.1, the Accessibility Guidelines Working Group is developing another major version of accessibility guidelines. The result of this work is expected to be a more substantial restructuring of web accessibility guidance than would be realistic for dot-releases of WCAG 2. The work follows a research-focused, user-centered design methodology to produce the most effective and flexible outcome, including the roles of content authoring, user agent support, and authoring tool support. This is a multi-year effort, so WCAG 2.1 is needed as an interim measure to provide updated web accessibility guidance to reflect changes on the web since the publication of WCAG 2.0. The Working Group might also develop additional interim versions, continuing with WCAG 2.2, on a similar short timeline to provide additional support while the major version is completed.

5. Conformance

5. Conformance
This section lists requirements for conformance to WCAG 2.1. It also gives information about how to make conformance claims, which are optional. Finally, it describes what it means to be accessibility supported, since only accessibility-supported ways of using technologies can be relied upon for conformance. Understanding Conformance includes further explanation of the accessibility-supported concept.
5.1 Interpreting Normative Requirements

5.1 Interpreting Normative Requirements
The main content of WCAG 2.1 is normative and defines requirements that impact conformance claims. Introductory material, appendices, sections marked as "non-normative", diagrams, examples, and notes are informative (non-normative). Non-normative material provides advisory information to help interpret the guidelines but does not create requirements that impact a conformance claim.
The key words MAY, MUST, MUST NOT, NOT RECOMMENDED, RECOMMENDED, SHOULD, and SHOULD NOT are to be interpreted as described in [RFC2119].
5.2 Conformance Requirements

5.2 Conformance Requirements
In order for a Web page to conform to WCAG 2.1, all of the following conformance requirements must be satisfied:
5.2.1 Conformance Level
One of the following levels of conformance is met in full.
For Level A conformance (the minimum level of conformance), the Web page satisfies all the Level A Success Criteria, or a conforming alternate version is provided.
For Level AA conformance, the Web page satisfies all the Level A and Level AA Success Criteria, or a Level AA conforming alternate version is provided.

For Level AAA conformance, the Web page satisfies all the Level A, Level AA and Level AAA Success Criteria, or a Level AAA conforming alternate version is provided.
Note
Although conformance can only be achieved at the stated levels, authors are encouraged to report (in their claim) any progress toward meeting success criteria from all levels beyond the achieved level of conformance.
Note
It is not recommended that Level AAA conformance be required as a general policy for entire sites because it is not possible to satisfy all Level AAA Success Criteria for some content.
5.2.2 Full pages

5.2.2 Full pages
Conformance (and conformance level) is for full Web page(s) only, and cannot be achieved if part of a Web page is excluded.
Note
For the purpose of determining conformance, alternatives to part of a page's content are considered part of the page when the alternatives can be obtained directly from the page, e.g., a long description or an alternative presentation of a video.
Note
Authors of Web pages that cannot conform due to content outside of the author's control may consider a Statement of Partial Conformance.
Note

Note
A full page includes each variation of the page that is automatically presented by the page for various screen sizes (e.g. variations in a responsive Web page). Each of these variations needs to conform (or needs to have a conforming alternate version) in order for the entire page to conform.
5.2.3 Complete processes

5.2.3 Complete processes
When a Web page is one of a series of Web pages presenting a process (i.e., a sequence of steps that need to be completed in order to accomplish an activity), all Web pages in the process conform at the specified level or better. (Conformance is not possible at a particular level if any page in the process does not conform at that level or better.)
An online store has a series of pages that are used to select and purchase products. All pages in the series from start to finish (checkout) conform in order for any page that is part of the process to conform.

5.2.4 Only Accessibility-Supported Ways of Using Technologies
Only accessibility-supported ways of using technologies are relied upon to satisfy the success criteria. Any information or functionality that is provided in a way that is not accessibility supported is also available in a way that is accessibility supported. (See Understanding accessibility support.)
5.2.5 Non-Interference

5.2.5 Non-Interference
If technologies are used in a way that is not accessibility supported, or if they are used in a non-conforming way, then they do not block the ability of users to access the rest of the page. In addition, the Web page as a whole continues to meet the conformance requirements under each of the following conditions:
when any technology that is not relied upon is turned on in a user agent,
when any technology that is not relied upon is turned off in a user agent, and
when any technology that is not relied upon is not supported by a user agent

when any technology that is not relied upon is not supported by a user agent

1.4.2 - Audio Control,
2.1.2 - No Keyboard Trap,
2.3.1 - Three Flashes or Below Threshold, and
2.2.2 - Pause, Stop, Hide.

5.4 Statement of Partial Conformance - Third Party Content

5.4 Statement of Partial Conformance - Third Party Content
Sometimes, Web pages are created that will later have additional content added to them. For example, an email program, a blog, an article that allows users to add comments, or applications supporting user-contributed content. Another example would be a page, such as a portal or news site, composed of content aggregated from multiple contributors, or sites that automatically insert content from other sources over time, such as when advertisements are inserted dynamically.

In these cases, it is not possible to know at the time of original posting what the uncontrolled content of the pages will be. It is important to note that the uncontrolled content can affect the accessibility of the controlled content as well. Two options are available:

A determination of conformance can be made based on best knowledge. If a page of this type is monitored and repaired (non-conforming content is removed or brought into conformance) within two business days, then a determination or claim of conformance can be made since, except for errors in externally contributed content which are corrected or removed when encountered, the page conforms. No conformance claim can be made if it is not possible to monitor or correct non-conforming content;
OR

OR
A "statement of partial conformance" may be made that the page does not conform, but could conform if certain parts were removed. The form of that statement would be, "This page does not conform, but would conform to WCAG 2.1 at level X if the following parts from uncontrolled sources were removed." In addition, the following would also be true of uncontrolled content that is described in the statement of partial conformance:
It is not content that is under the author's control.

It is not content that is under the author's control.
It is described in a way that users can identify (e.g., they cannot be described as "all parts that we do not control" unless they are clearly marked as such.)

The form of that statement would be, "This page does not conform, but would conform to WCAG 2.1 at level X if accessibility support existed for the following language(s):"

Responsive Web Design Testing: When doing Responsive Web testing for tablet or phone breakpoints on a desktop computer, you do not have to test this checkpoint again if it has already been done for the Desktop breakpoint. It is redundant to test again.
Open the page in Chrome. Ensure that Chrome is displaying the page at its actual size with the site's provided CSS. (In other words, no zoom, no magnification, no user supplied CSS features are turned on).

Resize the browser viewport to one of the following (all are the equivalent to 320px width at 100% zoom):
320px width by 256px height at 100% zoom OR
640px width by 512px height at 100% and then zoom to 200% OR

NOTE: Be sure to resize the viewport while at 100% zoom BEFORE applying the 200% or 400% zoom.

Things to think about

Things to think about
Just because a horizontal scrollbar appears when the screen is resized does not automatically mean this checkpoint is failed! Sometimes a scrollbar may appear (due to extra CSS padding or a decorative element), but the text can all be seen in the viewport width and fulfills this checkpoint.

"Content" is not a defined term in WCAG. For the purposes of this checkpoint, "content" can be thought of as self-contained portions of page content. Each portion of content is evaluated for scrolling in more than one direction. For example, the main body of the page reflows to 320px but certain portions of the page may scroll horizontally such as:

Individual carousel panels or slider cards (such as product carousel / slider on an ecommerce site or movie cards on a streaming site). The carousel or slider may scroll horizontally; however, each individual panel / card must fit horizontally within the viewport. (It is permissible for the individual panels to scroll vertically.)
Horizontal navigation menus. The menu bar may scroll horizontally; however, each individual menu item must fit horizontally within the viewport.

How much content is visible on a screen may change from the standard desktop view at different zoom levels, screen widths, or screen orientations due to responsive design changes. For example, navigation menus that are fully visible in a desktop layout are often collapsed into a single menu button (the 'hamburger' icon pattern), or sections of a screen may be collapsed under toggled controls so they take up less screen space. This checkpoint is passed as long as all information and functionality are still available either: directly on the screen, revealed via accessible controls on the same screen, accessible via direct links from the screen being assessed, or via clear instructions on how to locate the information or functionality.

Recommended tools to size the browser viewport
Chrome and Edge Developer Tools:
Open the Inspect panel. You may dock it to the side or the bottom of the main browser window or decouple it from the main browser window. Use the three vertical dots button ("Customize and control DevTools" button) in the upper right corner of the Developer Tools panel and select a placement from the "Dock side" options. NOTE: If you need the screen width to be less than 500px, you will need to dock the Inspect panel to the right side of the main browser window.
Ensure the browser zoom is set to 100%.

Ensure the browser zoom is set to 100%.
Resize the main browser window by dragging and view the size stats in the upper right corner of the browser window.
You can double-check the browser size by going to the Inspect panel > Console tab, and typing in window.innerWidth or window.innerHeight.
Web Developer browser extension for Chrome and Firefox:
Use Resize > Resize Window to set the Window width and height.

Use Resize > Resize Window to set the Window width and height.
Check the resulting Viewport size and adjust. NOTE: There is a difference between Window size and Viewport size. The Window size includes the browser toolbars above the Viewport and scrollbars. When you use "Resize Window" you are setting the Window size, not the Viewport size. To view and adjust the Viewport:
Use Resize > Display Window Size. This will display both the Window size AND the Viewport size. The Viewport height will be shorter than the desired height. The Viewport width may also be narrower than the desired width.

Use Resize > Window Size to adjust the Window height and/or width upward to compensate for the toolbars and scrollbars included in the Window size.
Repeat the two steps above until the height and width match the intended Viewport size.

1.4.12.a Text Spacing
Overview
General - The spacing between letters, words, lines of text and paragraphs must be adjustable to certain spacing guidelines without loss of content or functionality.

HTML - The spacing between letters, words, lines of text and paragraphs must be adjustable to certain spacing guidelines without loss of content or functionality.
Testing Methodology
Required for testing:
Sight or sighted assist
Desktop Web - Manual
Browser 1: Open the page in a browser with the viewport set to 1366px width by 768px height AND zoom set to 100%.
Browser 2: Open the page in a second browser with the viewport set to 1366px width by 768px height AND zoom set to 100%. Activate Dylan Barrell's 1.4.12 Text Spacing Bookmarklet .

Visually confirm that text spacing responds to the bookmarklet. The expected outcome is:
Line height (1.5 times the font size)
Spacing following paragraph (at least 2 times the font size)
Letter spacing (at least .12 times the font size)
Word spacing (at least .16 times the font size)
Note: If the text spacing requirements are met BEFORE the bookmarklet is applied, one should not expect an increase ABOVE the default appearance. For example, if the line spacing is already at least "1.5 times the font size", the test spacing bookmarklet is not expected to make the line spacing larger.

Compare the content and functionality available in the two browsers. Make sure there is no loss of content or functionality on the page where the "1.4.12 Text Spacing" bookmarklet has been applied.
Exceptions: Text spacing is not required for the following:
Video captions embedded directly into the video frame
PDF
Images of text
Options inside an HTML select dropdown or datalist dropdown
Text implemented in Canvas

Options inside an HTML select dropdown or datalist dropdown
Text implemented in Canvas

Identify the iframe element within the HTML.
Copy the URL in the src attribute of the iframe.

Copy the URL in the src attribute of the iframe.
Paste the URL in a new browser tab.
Run the bookmarklet.
